title: Police strip 250 revellers of their driving licences over e-scooter drunkenness in Munich
text:
German police said hundreds of drunken e-scooter riders at Oktoberfest this year lost their driving licences.

During the 16-day beer festival, officers in Munich stopped 414 people riding under the influence, with 254 of those losing their automobile licences immediately.

The rented two-wheelers, which were brought to German streets in June, caused such havoc they were banned from the festival grounds, with clear warnings not to drink and ride.

During the 16-day beer festival, officers in Munich stopped 414 people riding under the influence, with 254 of those losing their automobile licences immediately (pictured: a woman is breathalysed in Munich in July this year)

They are classed as motorised vehicles and as such, normal driving laws apply, something which police spokesman Marcus da Gloria Martins believes many did not realise.

He told Stern that most saw it as a 'lifestyle product or toy' and used the scooters without due care.

They caused 21 accidents during the festival which ended on Friday, 13 of those involved alcohol.

Around the festival grounds the police said they stopped 1,100 e-scooters from entering.

Policewomen speak to an e-scooter rider in Munich in July this year, shortly after the vehicles were legalised

A man holds a stein of beer aloft at the Oktoberfest festival in Munich, Germany on September 21

E-scooters have mobbed Munich and other German cities since they arrived earlier this year, allowing people to use apps to hire them for just €1 and then around 20 cents a minute thereafter.

They are restricted to 12mph and for use on cycle lanes but not pavements.

A drivers' licence is not required to use one but the same legal limits for alcohol apply and therefore, those who transgress can lose their automobile licences.
